thread.title: Manufacturing sector expands as strong demand bolsters builders, food and beverage makers
thread.title_full: Manufacturing sector expands as strong demand bolsters builders, food and beverage makers | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: JOHN CONROY
title: Manufacturing sector expands as strong demand bolsters builders, food and beverage makers
text:
AUSTRALIA’S manufacturing sector has expanded for a second straight month as residential building activity and strong demand for food and beverages fuels the industry, research suggests.
The Australian Industry Group’s performance of manufacturing index has climbed 1.3 points to 51.7 for August.
It builds on July's reading of 50.4 — also above the 50 point threshold that separates expansion and contraction.
In June, the index clocked in at 44.2, suggesting the sector was shrinking.
“A second month of expansion is encouraging for Australian manufacturing,” Ai Group chief Innes Willox said today.
“It is also positive for the economy overall which requires a broader base of growth as the mining investment boom continues to unwind.”
The recent results from the Australian PMI suggested output growth in manufacturing, measured as ‘value added’ by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, was likely to have been flat in recent months, Mr Willox said.
Four of the seven activity sub-indices expanded in August: new orders, after two months of contraction; production and supplier deliveries for a second month; and employment.
But sales returned to contraction and stock levels shrunk for a seventh month. Manufacturing exports also contracted in August after three months of expansion, Ai Group said.
Three of the eight manufacturing sub-sectors expanded: Food and beverages for a fifteenth month; wood and paper for a sixth month; and textiles, clothing, footwear, furniture and other manufacturing.
The progressive closure of local automotive assembly, and further declines in mining and other business investment in machinery and equipment “are heavily affecting other parts of manufacturing, with ongoing reports of business consolidation and closures”, Ai Group said.
“Despite the benefits from a lower Australian dollar and higher residential building activity on some building-related segments of chemicals production, [mining sub-sector] respondents raised concerns about a decline in exports to the Asian markets in recent months,” it said.
 Food, drinks fuel manufacturing
